Mountain" - Nuns * "End Credits" (instrumental) {{div col end}} ==Reception== ===Critical reception=== Prior to the broadcast, members of the real-life von Trapp family were critical of casting Underwood to play Maria, agreeing with the notion that she would be a good singer but a poor actor. They suggested that [[Anne Hathaway]], who played [[Fantine]] in the [[Les Misérables (2012 film)|2012 film adaptation]] of ''[[Les Misérables (musical)|Les Misérables]]'' for which she won the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]], would have been a better choice.{{cite web|last=Rothman|first=Michael|title=Who the Von Trapps Wish Could Replace Carrie Underwood in ‘The Sound of Music Live’|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/entertainment/2013/12/who-the-von-trapps-wish-could-replace-carrie-underwood-in-the-sound-of-music-live/|work=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=December 6, 2013|date=December 5, 2013}} ''The Sound of Music Live!'' received mixed reviews from entertainment critics, commending the show for its scope and supporting cast while questioning Underwood's acting capabilities. Kevin Fallon of ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' wrote: "Naturally, Underwood sounded astounding, as alive as those damned hills, every time she was asked to stand on top of things and belt. But whether it was because of nerves or lack of experience, her acting was painfully lifeless and amateur throughout the first two thirds of the lengthy ordeal. The singer, it seems, is a proud graduate of the school of 'If I don't blink, they'll think I'm acting!'"{{cite web|title=‘Sound of Music Live!’ Review: The Hills Are Barely Alive| url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/12/06/sound-of-music-live-review-the-hills-are-barely-alive.html|work=[[The Daily Beast]]|publisher=[[The Newsweek Daily Beast Company]]|last=Fallon|first=Kevin|date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 6, 2013}} Verne Gay of ''[[Newsday]]'' liked Underwood's performance, commenting that not only could she sing, but "she is a luminous stage presence who had the guts to take on one of the most iconic roles of the stage or screen."{{Cite web|url = http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/columnists/verne-gay/sound-of-music-and-carrie-underwood-largely-a-success-1.6550556|title = 'Sound of Music' -- and Carrie Underwood -- largely a success|date = December 5, 2013|accessdate =December 6, 2013|work = [[Newsday]]|publisher=[[Cablevision]]|last = Gay|first = Verne}} Brian Lowry of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' described the production "as lifeless as [its] alpine backdrops."{{cite web |title=TV Review: '' 'The Sound of Music Live!' '' |url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/reviews/the-sound-of-music-live-tv-review-nbc-1200915170/ |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|last=Lowry|first=Brian |date= December 5, 2013|accessdate=December 6, 2013}} Marc Bernardin of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' commended the production's aesthetics but called it a "very expensive karaoke", and he wrote that Underwood "doesn’t acquit herself so well when it comes to the carrying the emotional weight of the production." He also panned Moyer, criticizing his vocal performance and describing "his attempt at conveying an emotional hollowness" as "mildly constipated" and "clenched." However, he lauded Benanti, Borle and McDonald's "strong" performances.{{Cite web|url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/sound-music-live-tv-review-663346|title = The Sound of Music Live!: TV Review|date =December 5, 2013|accessdate=December 6, 2013|work = [[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|last = Bernardin|first = Marc}} ===Ratings=== 18.62 million viewers watched ''The Sound of Music Live!'', making it the most-watched program of the night. It had a 4.6 rating, 13 share in the 18–49 demographic, which led all networks.{{cite news |url= http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/12/06/thursday-final-ratings-the-big-bang-theory-once-upon-a-time-the-millers-greys-anatomy-scandal-adjusted-down/220522/ |title=Thursday Final Ratings: 'The Big Bang Theory' & 'The X Factor' Adjusted Up; 'Once Upon a Time in Wonderland', 'The Millers', 'Grey's Anatomy' & Scandal' Adjusted Down|last=Kondolojy|first=Amanda |date=December 6, 2013 |work=TV by the Numbers|accessdate=December 7, 2013}} It attracted NBC's largest non-sports Thursday audience since the [[Goodnight, Seattle|series finale]] of ''[[Frasier]]'' in 2004 (which averaged 22.6 million viewers),{{cite news |url=http://tvline.com/2013/12/06/sound-of-music-live-ratings-nbc/ |title=Ratings: NBC's Sound of Music Live! Does Something Very Good; Glee and Grey's Eye Lows |last=Mitovich|first=Matt Webb |date=December 6, 2013 |work=TVLine |accessdate=December 7, 2013}} and NBC's largest non-sports audience on any night since the [[2007 Golden Globe Awards]].{{cite news |url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/tv/tv-zone-1.811968/the-sound-of-music-live-ratings-18-5-million-viewers-1.6554021 |title='The Sound of Music Live!' ratings: 18.5 million viewers |last=Gay |first=Verne |work=[[Newsday]] |date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 7, 2013}} The special performed the best with women in the 25–54 demographic, reaching a household rating of 7.0 for that demographic during the primetime broadcast.{{cite news |url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/sound-of-music-ratings-sing-for-nbc-thursday-night-1200925968/ |title='Sound of Music' Ratings Sing for NBC Thursday Night |last=Weisman |first=Jon |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 7, 2013}} It did particularly well in Oklahoma City, the capital of Underwood's home state, where it was watched by 28% of TV viewers.{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2013/12/06/sound-of-music-live-nbc-ratings/3890653/ |title='Sound of Music' was ratings high|last=Levin |first=Gary|work=[[USA Today]] |publisher=[[Gannett Company]] |date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 7, 2013}} At least 38.69 million viewers watched a portion of ''The Sound of Music Live!''. Factoring in DVR viewership over the week following the broadcast, the special was viewed by 21.84 million, with 3.1 million within the first three days.{{cite web|title=‘The Sound Of Music’ Continues To Echo Across The Ratings Landscape|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/12/the-sound-of-music-continues-to-echo-across-the-ratings-landscape/|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=24 December 2013}}{{cite web|title=Ratings for The Sound of Music Live! Swell to Nearly 22 Million with DVR Playback|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/185818-Ratings-for-The-Sound-of-Music-Live-Swell-to-Nearly-22-Million-with-DVR-Playback|work=Playbill|accessdate=24 December 2013}}{{cite web|title=Live ‘Sound of Music’ Added 3 Million Delayed Viewers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/11/business/media/live-sound-of-music-added-3-million-delayed-viewers.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|last=Carter|first=Bill|date=December 10, 2013|accessdate=December 11, 2013}} Following its original airing, an encore presentation of ''The Sound of Music Live!'' aired on December 14, 2013, attracting 3.1 million viewers. It notably displaced one of NBC's two traditional airings of the film ''[[It's a Wonderful Life]]'' (the other being on Christmas Eve), which was bumped ahead to December 20, 2013.{{cite journal|last=Friedlander|first=Whitney|title=NBC to Re-Air ‘The Sound of Music Live!’|journal=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=December 10, 2013|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/nbc-sound-of-music-live-reair-1200941859/|accessdate=December 14, 2013}}{{cite journal|last=Strecker|first=Erin|title=NBC to re-air 'Sound of Music Live!' on Saturday|journal=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher= Entertainment Weekly Inc|date=December 10, 2013|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2013/12/10/sound-of-music-live-encore/|accessdate=December 13, 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.journalnow.com/news/ask_sam/article_251bd091-1888-5c87-86d8-8137dc17cedf.html|title=Ask Sam: 'It's a Wonderful Life' pre-empted by 'Sound of Music Live'|work=[[Winston-Salem Journal]]|publisher=[[Berkshire Hathaway|BH Media]]|date=December 20, 2013|accessdate=December 20, 2013}} NBC's Bob Greenblatt considered the production to be a success, and signed Meron and Zadan to produce another live musical for the 2014 holiday season. Greenblatt felt that there were enough recognizable, family-friendly musicals to make events like ''The Sound of Music Live!'' an annual tradition, and he indicated that NBC received e-mails and phone calls from various theatrical rightsholders, expressing interest in having their musicals adapted in a similar fashion, In January 2014, NBC announced that it would broadcast a live version of ''[[Peter Pan Live!|Peter Pan]]'' in December 2014, and at NBC's [[upfronts]] in May 2014, Greenblatt announced that NBC had also obtained rights to produce an adaptation of ''[[The Music Man]]'', although the network did not announce any timeframe for the production.{{cite web|title=NBC Says It Will Put On a Show, Again| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/10/arts/television/a-network-is-buoyed-by-sound-of-music-ratings.html?ref=television&_r=0|work=[[The New York Times]]|last=Carter|first=Bill|date=December 9, 2013|accessdate=December 10, 2013}}{{cite web|title=NBC Announces 'Music Man' Live TV (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=November 17, 2014 }} It was later revealed that ''The Music Man'' project was put on hold for a live performance of ''[[The Wiz Live!|The web|title='Grease' Live Coming to Fox TV|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6070137/grease-live-coming-to-fox-tv|website=Billboard|accessdate=5 December 2014}} NBC aired ''[[Hairspray {{dablink|For other uses, see [[To the Last Man (disambiguation)]]}} {{Infobox book | | name = To the Last Man | title_orig = | translator = | image = ZaneGrey ToTheLastMan.jpg | caption = | author = [[Zane Grey]] | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = [[Western (genre)|Western]]| publisher = [[Harper & Brothers]] (US hardback) &
[[Forge]] (US paperback) | release_date = 1921 | media_type = Print ([[Hardback]] & [[Paperback]]) | pages = 311 pp (hardback); 288 pp (paperback edition) | isbn = 0-8125-6465-0 | isbn_note = (paperback edition) | congress= CPB Box no. 2090 vol. 18 | oclc= 45577928 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''To the Last Man: A Story of the Pleasant Valley War''''' is a western novel written by [[Zane Grey]]. ==Origin== ''To The Last Man'' is a shorter version of ''[[Tonto Basin (novel)|Tonto Basin]]''. Grey submitted the manuscript of ''Tonto Basin'' to the magazine ''The Country Gentleman,'' which published it in serialization as ''To the Last Man'' from May 28, 1921 through July 30, 1921. This was a much shorter version of the original leaving out much of the [[backstory]]. This shorter version was published by [[Harper Brothers]]. ==Plot introduction== It is a story of a family feud healed by young love. The story is based on a factual event involving the notorious Hashknife gang of Northern Arizona. ==Plot summary== The story follows an ancient feud between two frontier families that is inflamed when one of the families takes up cattle rustling. The ranchers are led by Jean Isbel and, on the other side, Lee Jorth and his band of cattle rustlers. In the grip of a relentless code of loyalty to their own people, they fight the war of the Tonto Basin, desperately, doggedly, to the last man, neither side seeing the futility of it until it is too late. And in this volatile environment, young Jean finds himself hopelessly in love with a girl from whom he is separated by an impassable barrier. ==Characters in "To the Last Man"== *Jean Isbel – Jean Isbel is a woodsman from Oregon drawn into the Tonto Basin feud by his father, Gaston Isbel. He has the reputation of being an excellent tracker and fighter. He is born from Gaston's second wife, who was Native American. He is in love with Ellen Jorth. *Gaston Isbel – Gaston Isbel is a Texas cattleman ranching in the Tonto Basin. He is involved in an old feud with Lee Jorth. He calls his son Jean Isbel into the feud in the hope that Jean will help him win the feud. *Lee Jorth – Lee Jorth is an ex-cattleman from Texas involved in an old feud with Gaston Isbel. He is supposedly a sheep herder running sheep on the cattle's range in the Tonto Basin. He is involved with many shady characters, including the notorious Hashknife gang. His daughter is Ellen Jorth. *Ellen Jorth – is the daughter of Lee Jorth; is caught meeting Jean Isbel early in the story but because of the family feud cannot related to him as she might like. She is told lies by her father and placed in situations where she must uphold her family but secretly being in love with Jean. *Colter – part of the Jorth group. *Greaves – store keeper and part of the Jorth group. *Bill – half brother to Jean Isbel; son of Gaston Isbel. *Guy – half brother to Jean Isbel; son of Gaston Isbel. *Jim Blaisdell – neighbor rancher to Gaston Isbel. *John Sprague – old prospector lived near Jorth; was good friend to Ellen. *Daggs – sheepman, part of the Jorth group. *Blue – older gunslinger from Texas who tells them he is really King Fisher the famous gunfighter; this brings fear to the sheepmen. ==See also== {{portal|Novels}} * [[To the Last Man (1923 film)|''To the Last Man'' (1923 film)]] * [[To the Last Man (1933 film)|''To the Last Man'' (1933 film)]], a 1933 [[Henry Hathaway]] film based on the [[Zane Grey]] novel starring [[Randolph Scott]], [[Esther Ralston]], [[Buster Crabbe]], [[Barton MacLane]], [[Noah Beery]], [[Shirley Temple]], and [[Eugenie Besserer]]. * [[Frederick Russell Burnham]] participated on the losing side in the real-life Tonto Basin feud and narrowly escaped alive. After the feud, he went home to California and left for Africa only a few years later.{{cite book | last =Burnham | first =Frederick Russell | authorlink =Frederick Russell Burnham | coauthors = | title =Scouting on Two Continents | publisher =Doubleday, Page and Co | year =1926 | location = New York | pages = Chapters 3 & 4| url = | doi = | id = ASIN B000F1UKOA | nopp =true | isbn =0-86920-126-3 }}{{cite journal| author =R. R. Money| date=April 1962| title=Tonto Basin Feud | journal=[[Blackwood's Magazine]]| volume=291| issue=| issn=0006-436X }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Gutenberg|no=2070|name=To the Last Man}} * {{librivox book | title=To the Last Man | author=Zane GREY}} [[Category:1921 American novels]] [[Category:Western (genre) novels]] [[Category:Novels by Zane Grey]] [[Category:Works based on actual events]] [[Category:Novels set in Arizona]]

'''Multiple endings''' refer to a case in entertainment where the story could end in different ways.
==Comics== * ''[[The Death-Ray]]'' by [[Daniel Clowes]]. * ''[[Cliff Hanger (comic strip)|Cliff Hanger]]''.<ref> by [[Jack Edward Oliver]]. {{cite book|last=Oliver|first=Jack Edward|title=Buster|date=25 June 1983|publisher=Fleetway}}</ref>
==Literature== * The ''[[Choose Your Own Adventure]]'' series. * ''[[Life's Lottery]]''
==Theater==
*[[Ayn Rand]]'s 1934 play ''[[Night of January 16th]]'' allowed the audience to affect the ending by acting as the "jury" and voting the defendant "innocent" or "guilty".<ref>{{cite book |ref=harv |title=[[The Passion of Ayn Rand]] |last=Branden |first=Barbara |authorlink=Barbara Branden |location=Garden City, New York |publisher=Doubleday & Company |year=1986 |isbn=0-385-19171-5 |oclc=12614728 |pages=122–124}}</ref> *The 1985 musical ''[[The Mystery of Edwin Drood (musical)|The Mystery of Edwin Drood]]''. *[[Dario Fo]]'s 1970 play, ''[[Accidental Death of an Anarchist]]''. *The long-running play ''[[Shear Madness]]'' has multiple, audience-selected endings
==Films== DVDs may include an [[alternate ending]] as a special feature. These are usually not considered [[canon (fiction)|canon]].
Films which include multiple endings within the main cut of the film:
*''[[Clue (film)|Clue]]'' *''[[Wayne's World (film)|Wayne's World]]'' and its sequel, ''[[Wayne's World 2]]'' *''[[Scarface (1932 film)|Scarface]]'' *''[[Sliding Doors]]'' *''[[Run Lola Run]]'' *''[[Harikrishnans]]'' *''[[28 Days Later]]''
==Animation== *''[[Dragon's Lair]]'' and ''[[Space Ace]]'' *The [[Red vs. Blue (season 5)|fifth season]] finale of the [[Rooster Teeth]] web-series, ''[[Red vs. Blue]]''
==Video games== {{see also|Nonlinear gameplay}} {{see also|Category:Video games with alternate endings}}
==See also== * [[Alternate ending]] * [[Interactive fiction]] * [[Visual novel]]

{{external links|date=July 2015}} The term '''use error''' has recently been introduced to replace the commonly used terms '''[[human error]]''' and '''[[user error]]'''. The new term, which has already been adopted by [[international standard]]s organizations for [[medical device]]s (see [[#Use errors in health care]] below for references), suggests that [[accident]]s should be attributed to the circumstances, rather than to the human beings who happened to be there.
==The need for the terminological change== The term "use error" was first used in May 1995 in an [[MD+DI]] guest editorial, [http://www.mddionline.com/article/issue-use-not-user-error “The Issue Is ‘Use,’ Not ‘User,’ Error,”] by [http://biomed.tamu.edu/people/faculty.php?lname=Hyman William Hyman].<ref>http://www.mddionline.com/article/issue-use-not-user-error</ref> Traditionally, human errors are considered as a special aspect of [[human factors]]. Accordingly, they are attributed to the human [[Computer operator|operator]], or [[user (computing)|user]]. When taking this approach, we assume that the system design is perfect, and the only source for the use errors is the human operator. For example, the [[U.S. Department of Defense]] (DoD) [[HFACS]] <ref>[http://uscg.mil/careercentral/cg113/docs/ergo_hfacs/hfacs.pdf], Department of Defense Human Factors Analysis and Classification System: A mishap investigation and data analysis tool</ref> classifies use errors attributed to the human operator, disregarding improper design and configuration setting, which often result in missing [[alarms]], or in inappropriate [[alert messaging|alerting]].
The need for changing the term was due to a common [[malpractice]] of the [[Project stakeholder|stakeholder]]s (the responsible organizations, the authorities, journalists) in cases of accidents.<ref>[http://www.lu.se/upload/Trafikflyghogskolan/TR2002-01_ReInventionofHumanError.pdf], Dekker: Reinvention of Human Error</ref> Instead of investing in fixing the error-prone design, management attributed the error to the users. The need for the change has been pointed out by the accident investigators: * Early in 1983, Erik Hollnagel<ref> [https://sites.google.com/site/erikhollnagel2/], Erik Hollnagel home page </ref> pointed out that the term Human Error refers to the outcome, not to the cause. A user action is typically classified as an error only if the results are painful <ref>[http://www.ida.liu.se/~eriho/Bellagio_M.htm], Hollnagel: Why "Human Error" is a Meaningless Concept</ref> * In the story “Leap of Faith” of his book “Set Phasers on Stun”,<ref>[http://www.aegeanpublishing.com/phaser1.html], Steve Casey: Set Phasers on Stun</ref> Steve Casey suggested that the accident of the [[Indian Airlines Flight 605]] near Bangalor in 1990 could have been avoided, should the investigators of the [[Air France Flight 296]] accident of 1988 past the Mulhouse-Habsheim airport considered the circumstances (exceptional situation), rather than the pilots (human errors). * In his book “Managing the Risks of Organizational Accidents” ([[Organizational models of accidents]]) James Reason explained and demonstrated that often, the circumstances for accidents could have been controlled by the responsible organization, and not by the operators. * In his book “The Field Guide to Understanding Human Errors”,<ref>[http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9780754648260], Sidney Dekker: The Field Guide to Understanding Human Error</ref> Sidney Dekker argued that blaming the operators according to “The Old View” results in defensive behavior of operators, which hampers the efforts to learn from near-misses and from accidents.
==Use errors vs. force majeure== A mishap is typically considered as either a use error or a force majeure: <ref name="Weiler">[http://avi.har-el.com/eng/Articles/ITS-Alarms-Apr2011.pdf], Weiler and Harel: Managing the Risks of Use Errors: The ITS Warning Systems Case Study</ref> * A use error is a mishap in which a human operator is involved. Typically, such mishaps are attributed to the failure of the human operator <ref> [http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9780754648260], Dekker, 2007: The Field Guide to Understanding Human Error </ref> * A force majeure is a mishap that does not involve a human being in the chain of events preceding the event.
==Use errors in health care== In 1998, Cook, Woods and Miller presented the concept of [[hindsight bias]], exemplified by celebrated accidents in medicine, by a workgroup on patient safety .<ref> [http://www.ctlab.org/documents/A%20Tale%20of%20Two%20Stories.pdf], Cook RI, Woods DD, Miller C [1998] A Tale of Two Stories: Contrasting Views of Patient Safety </ref> The workgroup pointed at the tendency to attribute accidents in health care to isolated human failures. They provide references to early research about the effect of knowledge of the outcome, which was unavailable beforehand, on later judgement about the processes that led up to that outcome. They explain that in looking back, we tend to oversimplify the situation that the actual practitioners faces. They conclude focusing on the hindsight knowledge prevents our understanding of the richer story, the circumstances of the human error.
According to this position, the term Use Error is formally defined in several [[international standard]]s, such as [[International Electrotechnical Commission|IEC]] 62366, [[ISO 14155]] and [[ISO 14971]], to describe : ''an act or omission of an act that results in a different medical device response than intended by the manufacturer or expected by the user.''
[[ISO standards]] about medical devices and procedures provide examples of use errors, which are attributed to human factors, include slips, [[lapses]] and mistakes. Practically, this means that they are attributed to the user, implying the user’s accountability. The U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] glossary of medical devices provides the following explanation about this term:<ref>[http://www.fda.gov/MedicalDevices/ProductsandMedicalProcedures/GeneralHospitalDevicesandSupplies/InfusionPumps/ucm202502.htm], FDA, Medical Devices, Glossary</ref>
:"Safe and effective use of a medical device means that users do not make errors that lead to injury and they achieve the desired medical treatment. If safe and effective use is not achieved, use error has occurred. Why and how use error occurs is a [[human factors]] concern."
With this interpretation by ISO and the FDA, the term ‘use error’ is actually synonymous with ‘user error’. Another approach, which distinguishes ‘use errors’ from ‘user errors', is taken by IEC 62366. Annex A includes an explanation justifying the new term: :"This International Standard uses the concept of use error. This term was chosen over the more commonly used term of “human error” because not all errors associated with the use of medical device are the result of oversight or carelessness of the part of the user of the medical device. Much more commonly, use errors are the direct result of poor user interface design."
This explanation complies with “The New View”, which Sidney Dekker suggested as an alternative to “The Old View”. This interpretation favors investigations intended to understand the situation, rather than blaming the operators.
In a 2011 report draft on health IT usability, the U.S. [[National Institute of Standards and Technology]] (NIST) defines "use error" in healthcare IT this way: “Use error is a term used very specifically to refer to user interface designs that will engender users to make errors of commission or omission. It is true that users do make errors, but many errors are due not to user error per se but due to designs that are flawed, e.g., poorly written messaging, misuse of color-coding conventions, omission of information, etc.".<ref>''NISTIR 7804: Technical Evaluation, Testing and Validation of the Usability of Electronic Health Records, Draft, Sept. 2011, pg. 10. '' [https://www.nist.gov/healthcare/usability/upload/Draft_EUP_09_28_11.pdf]</ref>
=== Example of user error === An example of an accident due to a user error is the ecological disaster of 1967 caused by the [[Torrey Canyon]] supertanker. The accident was due to a combination of several exceptional events, the result of which was that the supertanker was heading directly to the rocks. At that point, the captain failed to change the course because the steering control lever was inadvertently set to the Control position, which disconnected the rudder from the wheel at the helm.<ref>Steve Casey, A memento of your service, in Set Phasers on Stun, 1998</ref>
===Examples of user failure to handle system failure=== Examples of the second type are the [[Three Mile Island accident]] described above, the [[New York City blackout of 1977|NYC blackout]] following a storm and the chemical plant disaster in Bhopal, India ([[Bhopal Disaster]]).
==Classifying use errors== The URM Model <ref name="Task-oriented"> [http://avi.har-el.com/eng/Articles/Task-Oriented-SE.pdf], Zonnenshain & Harel: Task-oriented SE, INCOSE 2009 Conference, Singapore</ref> characterizes use errors in terms of the user’s failure to manage a system deficiency. Six categories of use errors are described in a URM document: #Expected faults with risky results; #Expected faults with unexpected results; #Expected user errors in identifying risky situations (this study); #User Errors in handling expected faults; #Expected errors in function selection; #Unexpected faults, due to operating in exceptional states.
==Critics== Erik Hollnagel argues that going from and 'old' view to a 'new' view is not enough. One should go all the way to a 'no' view. This means that the notion of error, whether user error or use error might be destructive rather than constructive. Instead, he proposes to focus on the performance variability of everyday actions, on the basis that this performance variability is both useful and necessary. In most cases the result is that things go right, in a few cases that things go wrong. But the reason is the same. <ref> [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?arnumber=1042821] Hollnagel: Understanding accidents-from root causes to performance variability </ref> Hollnagel expanded on this in his writings about the [[efficiency–thoroughness trade-off principle]] <ref> [http://functionalresonance.com/ETTO_Introduction.html], The ETTO Principle – Efficiency-Thoroughness Trade-Off </ref> of Resilience Engineering, <ref> [http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9781409410355] Hollnagel, Paries, Woods, Wreathall (editors): Resilience engineering in practice </ref> and the Resilient Health Care Net. <ref> [http://www.resilienthealthcare.net] the Resilient Health Care Net </ref>
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_catalogue/catalogue_tc/catalogue_detail.htm?csnumber=38594 IEC 62366:2007 - Medical devices -- Application of usability engineering to medical devices] * [http://uscg.mil/careercentral/cg113/docs/ergo_hfacs/hfacs.pdf Department of Defense Human Factors Analysis and Classification System: A mishap investigation and data analysis tool] * [http://avi.har-el.com/eng/Articles/ITS-Alarms-Apr2011.pdf Managing the Risks of Use Errors: The ITS Warning Systems Case Study ] * [http://www.lu.se/upload/Trafikflyghogskolan/TR2002-01_ReInventionofHumanError.pdf The re-invention of human error] * [http://www.ida.liu.se/~eriho/Bellagio_M.htm Why "Human Error" is a Meaningless Concept] * [http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9780754648260 Dekker: The Field Guide to Understanding Human Error] * [http://www.fda.gov/MedicalDevices/ProductsandMedicalProcedures/GeneralHospitalDevicesandSupplies/InfusionPumps/ucm202502.htm FDA Medical Devices Glossary] * [http://sunnyday.mit.edu/ Nancy Leveson home page] * [http://www.ctlab.org/documents/A%20Tale%20of%20Two%20Stories.pdf Cook RI, Woods DD, Miller C 1998, A Tale of Two Stories] * [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?arnumber=1042821 Hollnagel: Understanding accidents-from root causes to performance variability] * [http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9781409410355 Hollnagel, Paries, Woods, Wreathall (editors): Resilience engineering in practice] * [http://functionalresonance.com/ETTO_Introduction.html The ETTO Principle – Efficiency-Thoroughness Trade-Off] * [http://www.resilienthealthcare.net the Resilient Health Care Net] * [http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9780754648260 Dekker, 2007: The Field Guide to Understanding Human Error]

{{italic title}} '''''You Me Bum Bum Train''''' is an [[Interactive theatre]] performance devised by Kate Bond and Morgan Lloyd in 2004. The pair met as art students in Brighton, where they were studying illustration and film.<ref>[https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/you-me-bum-bum-train-all-aboard-for-the-ride-of-a-lifetime-a2473106.html ''Evening Standard'' interview, 11 August 2015.]</ref>
''You Me Bum Bum Train'' gained critical acclaim in the United Kingdom when it was awarded the [[Samuel Beckett Award|Oxford Samuel Beckett Theatre Trust prize]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.barbican.org.uk/news/artformnews/theatredance/you-me-bum-bum-train |accessdate=June 30, 2010 |title=Barbican announces Oxford Samuel Beckett Theatre Trust award-winner|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100730232240/http://www.barbican.org.uk/news/artformnews/theatredance/you-me-bum-bum-train |archivedate=July 30, 2010 }}</ref> while showing in a disused office in London. In 2010 it won the [[Evening Standard Theatre Award]] for outstanding newcomer.
It returned in 2012 in a former postal depot in [[Holborn]], and a new version of the show – at Empire House in Stratford, east London in 2012 – was nominated for an [[Olivier Award]] for Outstanding Achievement in an Affiliate Theatre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olivierawards.com/nominations/view/item137190/outstanding-achievement-in-an-affiliate-theatre/ |accessdate=April 29, 2013 |title=Outstanding Achievement in an Affiliate Theatre - Olivier Awards|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130402194001/http://www.olivierawards.com/nominations/view/item137190/outstanding-achievement-in-an-affiliate-theatre/ |archivedate=April 2, 2013 }}</ref>
In 2015 the show was mounted again, this time in at what had been [[Foyles]] bookshop on London's [[Charing Cross Road]] where their last show, started on 25 February 2016, finished on 29 April.
==Overview== Visitors to the performance pass through a series of scenes of which they have no foreknowledge, in which they are either passive or where they must improvise a part without any preparation.<ref>{{cite web|author=Andrew Dickson |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/dec/11/best-theatre-2012-you-me-bum |title=Best theatre of 2012, No 9: You Me Bum Bum Train | Stage |publisher=Theguardian.com |date= |accessdate=2015-06-25}}</ref> Hanna Hanra, writing for ''Vice'', described it as a series of "highly detailed, absurd real life scenarios following one another on a nonsense high-paced narrative".<ref>[https://www.vice.com/en_uk/read/you-me-bum-bum-train-378 ''Vice'' interview, 19 June 2014.]</ref>
The entertainment magazine ''[[Dazed & Confused (magazine)|Dazed & Confused]]'' reported; "What was one of London's more obtuse treasures is set to become one of Great Britain's proudest moments." ''[[The Times]]'' said; "It leaves you questioning everything, and it's lots of fun."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/style/article1480556.ece|title=Album review|newspaper=[[The Times]]|accessdate=2015-06-25}}</ref> [[Time Out (company)|Time Out]] magazine wrote; "My highlight of 2008 was You Me Bum Bum Train, if only real life were that interesting."
==Controversies== ''You Me Bum Bum Train'' has provoked controversy due to the fact that none of the performers gets paid, though the directors stress that performers and crew are involved on a voluntary basis, that many are not trained professionals and that they are under no obligation to stay during performances.<ref>{{cite news|last=Barnett|first=Laura|title=You Me Bum Bum Train gives actors a bad ride, says union|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/jul/13/you-me-bum-bum-train-equity|accessdate=14 July 2012|newspaper=Theguardian.co.uk|date=13 July 2012|location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2010/07/equity-warns-sell-out-show-of-possible-minimum-wage-breach/|title=Equity warns sell-out show of possible minimum wage breach - News - The Stage|author=Natalie Woolman|work=Thestage.co.uk|accessdate=2015-06-25}}</ref>
The company was criticized for its ticketing system which caused problems for ticket buyers in June 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2015/ticketing-bum-bum-train-fire/|title=Ticketing for You Me Bum Bum Train under fire - Carousel, News - The Stage|author=Matthew Hemley|work=Thestage.co.uk|accessdate=2015-06-25}}</ref>
In November 2015 the trade union Equity criticised their £150,000 Arts Council England funding as YMBBT were advertising for professional dancers but were not paying them, despite selling tickets "at rates typical of a West End show." <ref>http://www.equity.org.uk/news-and-events/equity-news/equity-questions-arts-council-funding-decision/</ref> <ref>http://www.eventmagazine.co.uk/bum-bum-train-comes-fire-actors-union/agencies/article/1374456</ref>
In June 2016 the trade union BECTU criticised YMBBT for "exploiting workers after advertising for unpaid production interns." BECTU launched an investigation concerning "the legality of the “outrageous” internships, which would see successful applicants work at least two days each week for a minimum four hours each day." <ref>https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2016/bectu-launches-probe-exploitative-bum-bum-train-internships/</ref><ref>https://www.thestage.co.uk/opinion/2016/alistair-smith-show-producers-pay-stance-hits-a-bum-note/</ref>
